nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed applied microeconomics by centering research design and formalizing the causal interpretation of natural experiments and instrumental variables

Design-based empirical approach: emphasize identifying where treatment variation comes from, construct appropriate comparison groups, and validate identifying assumptions using institutional detail and targeted checks
Natural experiments and quasi-experiments provide credible treatment variation when randomization is infeasible, including large unanticipated shocks, administrative rules, thresholds, and lotteries

The potential outcomes framework and the LATE theorem formalize the interpretation of IV estimands when treatment effects are heterogeneous, clarifying assumptions (random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, relevance) and showing IV identifies the local average treatment effect for compliers
Design-based emphasis improves internal validity but raises external validity and generalizability concerns that require structural modeling or additional designs to extrapolate results
Card combined natural experiments with carefully constructed control groups and custom data collection to produce compelling empirical evidence on labor topics
Design-based studies prioritize transparent identifying assumptions (e.g., parallel trends, IV exclusion and monotonicity) and use placebo and balance checks to probe assumptions
Design-based research shifted empirical practice toward researcher- or administratively-collected data and new linkages beyond standard public microdata extracts

Empirical evidence: Card (1990) Mariel boatlift comparison of Miami to similar cities showed large low-skill immigration produced little change in native wages or employment, illustrating a research-design based natural experiment

Empirical evidence: Card and Krueger (1994) New Jersey minimum wage natural experiment (custom fast-food survey, NJ vs PA difference-in-differences) found no employment decline after a 20% minimum wage increase

Empirical evidence: Angrist and Krueger (1991) used quarter-of-birth as an instrument for schooling to estimate returns to education, finding roughly 10% earnings return per year for compliers induced by compulsory schooling rules

Empirical evidence: Angrist (1990) draft lottery as instrument for military service and Imbens, Rubin, and Sacerdote (2001) lottery winners study demonstrate using lotteries as as-good-as-random instruments to identify treatment effects for compliers

Conclusion: The laureates collectively strengthened the scientific foundation of economics by showing how transparent research design plus formal causal inference tools produce robust, interpretable evidence and guide synthesis across studies

Empirical-method interaction: combining experimental or quasi-experimental variation with structural or dynamic models (e.g., Card and Hyslop on SSP) enables interpretation beyond the local complier population and addresses policy extrapolation
